section.title: Cycles and disjoint cycle decomposition
section.p: There is another method of writing permutations which is preferred for group theory as it makes several special characteristics of permutations very visible.

statement.p: Suppose a\in A and \sigma\in S_A. Then \sigma fixes a, or equivalently a is a fixed point of \sigma, if and only if \sigma(a)=a. Elements of A which are not fixed by \sigma are moved by \sigma.

Let i_1, i_2, \ldots, i_r be distinct integers in [n], where n\geq r. Suppose \alpha\in S_n fixes all integers in [n]\setminus\set{i_1,i_2,\ldots,i_r} and also that
\alpha(i_1)=i_2, \alpha(i_2)=i_3, \ldots \alpha(i_{r-1})=i_r, \alpha(i_r)=i_1.

Then \alpha is an r-cycle, or equivalently a cycle of length r, and is denoted in cycle notation by
\alpha = (i_1~i_2~\cdots~i_r).

section.p: An interesting result of the definition of cycles is that every 1-cycle is equivalent to the identity: if a\in[n] and \alpha=(a), then \alpha(a) = a and for all b\in[n]\setminus\set{a}, b is fixed by \alpha, so \alpha(b)=b. Thus (a)=e for any a\in[n].

statement.p: Two cycles \alpha and \beta are disjoint if and only if every element moved by \alpha is fixed by \beta and every element moved by \beta is fixed by \alpha.
If \alpha and \beta are disjoint cycles in S_n, then \alpha\beta=\beta\alpha.
Every permutation is either a cycle or a product of disjoint cycles.

section.p: Moreover, this decomposition into disjoint cycles can be written uniquely up to the order in which the cycles appear!

example.title: Writing a permutation in disjoint cycle notation

statement.p:
Consider
g = \verb|8 1 5 9 4 6 7 3 10 2|.
We can write the cycle decomposition of g by starting with 1: the first cycle of the decomposition will be (1,g(1),g^2(1),g^3(1),\cdots,g^s(1)) for some s\leq n. In fact,
1 \mapsto 8 \mapsto 3 \mapsto 5 \mapsto 4 \mapsto 9 \mapsto 10 \mapsto 2 \mapsto 1
completes a cycle, and we also can see that g(6)=6 and g(7)=7. Hence the disjoint cycle notation for g is
g = (1,8,3,5,4,9,10,2)

While cycle notation is useful for many purposes, some find it difficult to multiply permutations written in their cycle decompositions. A rule to follow is this: the motion of symbols is evaluated from the right to the left. In order to discover the value of g^2, we write
g^2 = (1,8,3,5,4,9,10,2)(1,8,3,5,4,9,10,2)
and proceeding from right to left, we find that
1\mapsto 8 \amp\mapsto 3, \amp 3\mapsto 5 \amp\mapsto 4, \amp 4\mapsto 9 \amp\mapsto 10, \amp 10\mapsto 2 \amp\mapsto 1 \amp
and
2\mapsto 1 \amp\mapsto 8, \amp 8\mapsto 3 \amp\mapsto 5, \amp 5\mapsto \amp\mapsto 8, \amp 2\mapsto 1 \amp\mapsto 8. \amp
Hence
g^2 = (1,3,4,10)(2,8,5,9).

We can also compute powers of a permutation from its cycle decomposition by skipping through the cycles. For instance, rather than discovering g^3 by calculating g\cdot g^2, we can recognize that the image of 1 under g^3 must be the third number after 1 in the cyclic notation for g. Hence
g^3 \amp = (1,5,10,8,4,2,3,9), \amp g^4 \amp = (1,4)(2,5)(3,10)(8,9),
g^5 \amp = (1,9,3,2,4,8,10,5), \amp g^6 \amp = (1,10,4,3)(2,9,5,8),
g^7 \amp = (1,2,10,9,4,5,3,8), \text{\,and} \amp g^8 \amp = e.

exercise.title: Powers of permutations
exercise.statement: Use the preceding example an investigate higher powers of the permutation g.

statement.p: Suppose \sigma\in S_A is a permutation. Then the order of \sigma, denoted \abs{\sigma}, is the smallest positive integer n such that \sigma^n=e.
Suppose \alpha\in S_A is an r-cycle. Then \abs{\alpha}=r.

If \abs{S_A} is the number of permutationsIf there are n distinct elements in A, then \abs{S_A}=n!=n(n-1)(n-2)\cdots(3)(2)(1). of the set A and \sigma\in S_A, then there is an integer k such that k\abs{\sigma}=\abs{S_A}.

section.p: We are now equipped to see the real beauty of the cycle decomposition of a permutation.

statement.p:
Suppose \sigma\in S_A and \sigma=\alpha_1\alpha_2\cdots\alpha_k is its cycle decomposition. Then
\abs{\sigma}=\lcm\set{\abs{\alpha_i}:i\in[k]}.

Another beauty of cycle notation is that we see the behavior of certain powers of a permutation quite clearly. For example, if we let
\phi=(1~3~7~5)(2~4~6~8~9),
we can write \alpha=(1~3~7~5) and \beta=(2~4~6~8~9). Then \abs{\alpha}=4 and \abs{\beta}=5, and
\phi^5 = \alpha^5\beta^5 = \alpha^4\alpha e=\alpha
and
\phi^4 = \alpha^4\beta^4 = e\beta^{4} = \beta^{-1}.
